cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Ormus" will leave Suez about January 11
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about January 25.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orotava" will leave Port Said January 14
R.M.S. "Ophir" will leave Port Said Januuary 28

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May - 15th September.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Lesbos December 30 from Antwerp.
S.S. Androos Decmeber 30 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.

Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods. Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers issued. Foreign Exchange Bought and Sold. div.head: CASSA DI SCONTO E DI RISPARMIO.
div.p: A LIMITED LIABILITY COMPANY, AUTHORISED BY FIRMAN GRANTED BY H. H. THE KHEDIVE, JANUARY 25th, 1887.
CAPITAL 10,000,000 Frs. - RESERVE 2,659,552 Frs. 60 c.m.
Head Offices : ALEXANDRIA. - Branches : CAIRO, TANTAH, and ZAGAZIG.

The Cassa d Sconto e di Risparmio effects all Banking operations, such as Discount, Payments, Loans on Title, Deed, and Goods ; Letters of Credit issued. Drafts and telegraphic transfers on principal towns of Egypt and abroad. Custody of Titles Deeds, Purchase and sale of Debenture or other valuables ; Current accounts opened. The "Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio receives money in deposits at following rates: 2½ % for sight, 3½ % for 6 months, 4½ % for 1 year and over. The Savings Bank receives deposits from P.T. 20 up to 20,000 at the rate of 3½ % per annum. 28911- 23-11-907

div.p: London, Paris, Alexandria, Cairo, Malta, Gibraltar, Tantah, Mansurah and Port-Said.
Subscribed Capital £ 1,500,000, Paid up Capital £ 500,000, Reserve £ 550,000
The Bank undertakes every description of banking business on most favorable conditions.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d'Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l'étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

div.head: BANK OF ATHENS, LIMITED.
div.p: Head Office: Athens Capital Dr. 40,000,000 Fully Paid up) Reserve Da. 10,000,000

BRANCHES: London 55-56 Bishops gate-street Within-Alexandria, Cairo, Constantinople, Smyrna, Candia, Canes, Pitreus, Patras, Volo, Syra, Calamata, and Salonica. The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece, etc. Interests on cash deposits, 3% per ann. at sight: 3 1/2/0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4% for 13 months: 5% per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings Bank Branch receives deposits at 3 ½ % per ann. from P.T. 30 to P.T. 20,000.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,340,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

Siège Social au Caire, Succursale à Alexandria, Agence à Assiout, Assuoan, Benha, Beni-Suef, Chibin el Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Khartoum, Kéneh, Mansourah, Minieh, Port-Said, Suakin, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig, Mouski (Caire) et Londres (4 et 5, King William Street). La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d'Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d'un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d'un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

Special rates for Egyptian officials, members of Army of Occupation and their families.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.p: OF GREAT VALUE IN SICKNESS.
A unique and light diet for Invalids and Dyseptics.

It is very sustaining and nourishing is readily taken by those who cannot digest cow's milk, and is especially useul for the aged. It can be made in a minute, the addition of boiling water only being necessary. In Tins at 1/6 and 3/- of Chemlite, &c. A large sample sent for 3 penny stamps.
ALLEN & HANBURYS Ltd., 37, Lombard St., LONDON.
The "Allenburys" DIET is a food for Aduluts and is quite distinct from the well-known "Allenburys" Foods for Infants.

div.p: Helouan, near Cairo.

House warmed by special system of Radiators, adjoining the Golf Links and Race Course, Tennis, Billiards, Garden and open air palm house, good stabling , dark room. Excellent Table. Moderate Charges.

div.head: FRANCE IN THE LEVANT.
div.p: M. Chariot's attacks on French congregational education in the Near East have brought forth a well-considered and, we judge, well-merited refutation in a letter published by a Parisian journal, and which our contemporary the "Pyramides" re-prints at length. Without entering the arena of polemics which are not ours , to v-age, there are in this letter several very sound arguments that we feel it our duty to point out as a warning to a friendly Power. Foremost is the loss that France suffers by departing from the line of policy embodied in that famous dictum of Gambetta

'L'anticléricalisme n'est pas un article d'exportation." In so doing the Republic has ruined the splendid hegemony that Saint Louis bequeathed to the nation. She can no longer dictate to Turkey as the executor of Roman Qetholioism ; that prestige she has shattered by a too radical policy. Till the split with Rome, the name of "Frank" was identified, if not

identified, if not confounded by Turkish officialdom, with that of France. Now that the Republic shows signs of anti-clericalism there also, the numerous Christian communities who, subject to the Sultan, enjoyed nearly as many privileges as free-born Republican*, will be without such guarantee.

To come now to M. Chariot and his report. As the envoy of the French Foreign Office, his statements have led to the withdrawal from St. Benoît College at Çmyraa of twenty out of forty Turkish students whose -parents were alarmed at the allegations made therein. Father Gressien, rector of the University of Boy rout, considers, and rightly, the assertions of the Commissioner as likely to have serious consequences to French interests in the Orient, and the rector has met the charge of proselytism levelled against the scholastic friars by referring him to the Encyclical of Leo XIII., entitled Orientalism dignita»,

Crispi was in power, and after imposing on a none too elutic budget an annual burthen of 1,500,000 francs, she gave up the effort, and wisely submitted her educational interests to the I-atin congregations. Up till now, tbe selfsupporting scholastic institutions cost the French Treasury no more than 600,000 franca a year. What France is to-day so imprudently casting from her is an object which mo;e than one Roman Catholic Power has coveted. Austria sought it in 1870, and was much put out at being denied by Franoe. It was the goal of Bismarck's Near Eastern p*> licy, and he was no superficial student of Oriental politics. To-day the Kaiser, head of eighteen million Catholics, is watching the course of events which may one day lead him to a coup cFftat to which his landing at Tangier would be insignificant. What France abandons thus thoughtlessly, is what Russia aspires to secure for the furtherance of Pan-Slavism in the Near East : the protection of Orthodox Christians.. Christianity, whatever its form, needs the support of a European Power in Turkey, and that Power is the master of the situation.

div.head: St Mark's Churoh.
div.p: The preacher to morrow evening (6.15 p.m.) will be the Rev. C. Graham, M.A., chaplain ot H.M.8. Venns.

div.head: Murdsr In Alexandria.
div.p: A native woman in the Earmons quarter was found mordered in her room yesterday. The murderers are three natives, one of whom has been arrested.

div.head: Quarantine aralnst Jeddah.
div.p: Quarantine restrictions as against plague are applied to arrivals from Jeddah in.Tajkish and Egyptian ports. Turkey has imposed five days' quarantine.

div.head: Al Axhar University.
div.p: The results of the last examination at Al Azhar have been published. Sixty-five can didates passed, among them SO Hanefites, 21 Shafeite*, and 14 Male kites, out of a total of 169.

div.head: Alhambra.
div.p: The Diet French operatio troupe are giving ( a performance to night and to morrow night at the Alhambra. They aoted "Rigoletto" last night with considerable suooess. ft is amatter Cof regret that they are making so short a stay.

div.p: Miss 8wan acknowledges the following subscriptions towards the feast .--Mme Michel Sinadino 10s, Mrs. Bortpn 10s, Miss Dora Davies £1, Miss Tototte Sinano 15 frs., Miss Pennger 10s, Master Theodoraki 10s.

div.head: Military Leoture.
div.p: The eighth military leoture of the winter season will be delivered by Col. E.A. Herbert, M.V.O., Inniskilling Dragoons, on "Recruiting and the training of the Reoroit, especially Cavalry recruits. Items of the training in Ireland," at 6 p.m. on Tuesday evening next, in the Model Room at Headquarters, Cairo.

div.head: PrmetJoaJ Arab In Courses
div.p: That which is neoessary for foreigners, both resideot and tourist, in this country to know, is certainly not the literary Arabic, bat the ordinary conversational Arabio. Ia conee- qaence the Berlitz Schools (1, Sharia Kamel, Cairo ; and 12, rue Rosette, Alexandria) have instituted a oourse, which enables pupils in a very short time to obtain a sufficient knowledge of the language, to understand, and to moke themselves underotoo 1 very easily. [ADVT.] - Mess Egyptian Company.

div.head: New Egyptian Company
div.p: We onderstand that the firm of V. Levi & Co, of Alexandria, stock, share, and cotton brokers, is about to be transformed into an English'limited liability company onder the style of Levico, Limited, with a capital of £100,200, divided into 100,000 Ordinary shares of £1 each and 4,COO Deferred shares of Is. each. The firm has been established in Alexandria for over thirty years, and the partners oooupy a prominent position in the local financial world. The members of the company's board will be Messrs. Clement Castro, * Kamel Bey Teymonr, Victor Levi, Apostolo PriDgo, and Alfred Tilohe.

div.head: TheTi
div.p: Complaints as to the irregularity of the telephone service are as common in Egypt as in other connjtries, if not more so. There is this much, however, to be said for the company, and that is that the fault very often lies with the snbBoribero, without whose intelligent oooperation the proper working of telephor.es becomes impossible. The Telephone Company have therefore jast issaed an excellent set of instructions, by following wh:oh subscribers should have the minimum of trouble in their teUphonie communications. We are glad to see that ths company have adopted tbs system already in vogue in Europe, by whioh. the inesssant ridging of telephone bells is reduced to its lowest limits. In fature it will only bs necessary to give one or two sharp tarns to the handle of the teleph me. put the receiver to the ear, and await the reply of the operator, who will answer withoot ringing. Again, when one is oslled up, it will not be neoessary to ring, but simply put the receiver to the ear and commence the conversatiorvat the conolasion of whioh one mast "ring off.'' These sets of rales, which should do moob to make telephoniug a iSiss troab'esome operation, are being distributed to alj subscribers.

div.head:
GERMAN IMPERIALISM.
IMPORTANCE OF COLONIAL ISSUE.

div.p: The semi offioisl Press is vigorously urging the importance of the colonial issue. The ' NorddoutscheZoitung" daily publishes figures demonstrating the value of the Colonies, and especially Damaraland.(Reuter)

Herr Demborg addressed a conference of the representatives of the German Chambers of Commeroe. In a regular Imperialistic election speech, recalling Mr. Chamberlain, he stated that his Colonial policy meant the solution of the labour question and bread for millions by the employment of German oapital in trade. The indnstry and navigation of the world, he said, was rapidly becoming British. Germany was losing her importance owing to lack of oolonice, the way the ^British colonies were assimilating foreign immigrants and the way the Americans and Japanese were ousting the Germans from South Amerioa, China and elsewhere : the only possible counterpoise was the development of tte colonies. (Reuter)

div.head:
POPE AND FRANCE.
DEFENCE OF H.H.'S ATTITUDE

div.p: The Pope, in an Enoyolical, defending his attitude towards the French' legislation, repudiates the deBire to provoke a religious war and peroeontion. On the contrary be deploreB the sufferings involved, but is consoled by the union which the French Catholics have displayed. {Reuter)
An Euoyclieal declares that the last Briand law is spolittive and lees acceptable even than the Separation Law. (Havas,
M. Briston delivered a speech urging the Chamber to realise the social reform*.
The Senate has commenced the debate on tho Budget. ( Havas j
(Offioia1). A tidal wave has swept the west coast of Sumatra. 340 persons have been drowned in the islands of Tana and Pulo- Simalu. (Reuter)
An explosion has teken place in oellnloid stores of a factory at Geispolheim (Alsaor). The whole building was almost instantaneous'y ablaze. 21 youths and girls have been inoi nerated, \ ( V enter)
A fire has taken plaoe at a celluloid factory in the village of Geispolheim. 21 bodies have been recovered from the debris. (Havas
Owing to an informer the police here have arrested 100 Terrorists. They have also seized 43 Manser riflis and some revolvers. (Reuter)

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
AN ULTIMATUM.
div.p: The following is the text of a letter whioh has been addresfoi to the mombers of the 8pe- oial Committee on Economical Houses ot the Alexandria Municipality : —

Gentlemen, — The indifference and the amount of time taken to resolve one of the most vital and jest causes of the international element ofi&his town is amazing. For nearly 8 years oar commission has been working to promote a feeling of interest that some action should be taken at once and that the Government should without farther delay conoede sufficient ground for the hnildiDg of cheap blocks for private dwelling houses whioh at the present state ot rentals have become an imperative necessity.

We beg to inform yon that it nothing definite is come to, we aie compelled to destitute ourselves of the mandate given ns by the people and expose to them the work we have far done and inform them of the difficulties met and that all oar efforts have turned out vain and fruitless.

The above deoision was come to at a meeting held the 8th inst. We therefore hope yoa will at yonr first meeting pat forward our present deoision and give it snob consideration it neoesitates, as we cannot any further stay off the nnmerons and daily exaoting claims we are receiving from the mass of people that have appointed ns. p. Commission Internationale Permanante des maisons populaires The President,
L. Ronci.

div.head: IMPORTANT PROPERTY SALE.
div.p: As already announced by ns, the Daira Khassa has, in conjanotion with the Deotsoh- Orient Bank, acquired the plot of land oppo site the Hotel ' d'Angleterre on whioh are situated the ohnroh and schools of the German community of Cairo. The property consists of about 3,400 square metres, and the parchaae price was £57.10.0 per metre, which is a record figure for land in this district. Ten thousand pounds were paid on the signing of the contraot of sale yeaterdayk and the remainder of the amount is payable as follows : £60,000 on the 1st February and similar som on the 31st Deoember next, the balance baing due on the 31st December of next year. The two last payments aie to bear interest at the rate of 5 per oent. per annom, The property, whioh was a gift made by the Khedive Ismail to the German ooiony in 1869, is to be handed over on the lit Pebroary, 1908. In exchange for the above irofièrty the commnnity have bought 8,000 aquare metres' on the banks of the Lmaïlia Canal, near~ the new Italian Government schools at Bmlac, at the price of LE 11} the square metre. The same plot was offered for L E. 3 J sofpe six months ago.

div.head: CONTINENTAL COMPETITION IN EGYPT.
div.p: "A British Agent in JJgypt" writes to "African Engineering" : —

I eh mid like to oorreot an impression whioh statement made by yonr Cairo correspondent in a recent issna of "African Engineering" may have created. He leads one to believe that German engineering firms insist on cash payment g fqr their Bgyptiap orders. In the instance to whioh yonr correspondent refers this may have been true, but it is far from being the general role, as he seems to imply. My own e;perienge is tb%t one of the chiet deterrents to British trade in Egypt is the more exaoting demands of onr home firms in the way of payments. One company to whom I applied for a quota tion for several steam wagons insisted that the whole amount of the order should be paid before the vohioles left the works. In other words, they wanted me to fioanQe their business. This is not an isolated instanoe. Of course, snchabsurd terms are quite unacceptable when it is borne in mind that an agent is often expected to wait months for the greater portion of his money. On the other hand, the olftnse in German tender conpernijig payments generally stipulates that one quarter shall be paid on reoeipt of the order, one quarter on delivery, one quarter at the end of si; months, and the remainder within twelve months ot delivery. I need not dilate on the advantage to the purchaser offered by these terms, {t may, however, interest youy readers to bear that since I have induced several of my firms (all British) to adopt a similar policy I have been able to send thorn several good orders for machinery. Certainly, there is a Continental firm here—not a German fi<m—who sometimes aek for cash ; but this is quite an exceptional cas?. That particular fiim have been so successful, diplo matioal!yr in official circles tfiat they oau make praotigally what terms they like.

In conolnsion, I w juld like to point out that if British manufacturing engineers are to secure anything like their fair share of the Egyptian orders for maohinery whioh are sore to be pleoed with'0 the next few years they mast reoognise that the organisation qf their selling department b at least as important as the manufacturing section. They mast, therefor?, have good,- well-paid agents who are able to m!x sooially with those who plaos, or are able to infiuenos, orders. Their representatives must be engineers of the highest ability, haveautho rity to aot on their owu Initiative, and he able to advise purchasers as to what thty really want

div.head:
K. S. C.
SECOND SKYE MEETING.
div.p: The attendance at yesterday's 8kye. Meeting was somewhat disappointing. It cannot be denied that visitors have not arrived in snob quantities as in former years ; but there is still time, and with the weather as it i* in England, it will be strange if many people do not reek refuge in Egypt's sonny land. The racing was deoidedly good, very few horses being scratched. Atragak gave a wonderful display, winning his two raoe», and the last one 2 miles, in great style. This little horse haa^we hear, changed hands, Mr. Stoat, one of oar leading sportsmen, having pnrohased him. Mashkour, alas! we shall see no more on the race-oonrsc. A real game little horse, his final effort was wortey of him. Going his best to the very end, he finished third, and died on his way back to the stall. The horse had a great winning many good races, and his
hâte onr entire sympathy. The following are the results of the various events:—

div.head: NOTICE TO OWNERS.
div.p: Owing to a mistake in the Calendrier Egyptien the dates pub'ished in our issue of the 27th December last are not correot, and the following are the final and definite dates of the raoe meetings etc., in the coming season : -
April Skye Meeting, 6'h April.
Horse Show, 13'h April.
1st Summer Meeting, 55th and 27th April.
2nd Summer Meeting 6th (Shem el Nessim) and 11th May. .
3rd Summer Meeting 23rd and 25th May.
4th Summer Meeting, 6th and 8th Jane.

div.head: UNITED EGYPTIAN LANDS.
div.p: For the ii fjrmatior of shareholders in the United Egyptian Lande, Ltd., we have been requested to Btato that the directors bave today exeroised their option on the 57 feddans of land on Rodah Island and have paid the first instalment of £50,000 towards the purchase price.

The land is fivonrably situated, having a frontage on the Nile of 1,500 metres, and skirts the whole of the new Government road across the island. The total amount involved in the deal is half a million sterliog.

We onderstand that the company has reoeived some very good offers for building plots on the land, representing a large profit to the oimpany. A survey of the laud has been made, and the compaoy sxpeots to be soon in a position to offer plots for sale-

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. George Eid gave a charming afternoon party io hononr of Baron d'HeatreyT the sao* ceisor of Mr. Maskei s, on Thuriday. The guests visited the Barrage on the launoh Peljcir, and after exploring th* delightful gardens returned to tea on the launoh. Among the goests were Baton and Baroness Gaiffsr d'Hestroy, Chakour Pa^ha and Mme Chakour, M. and Mme Lamber, M. and Mms Bretsohneider, M. Charles Camel-raeg, M. and MIle.Rolin, and many others.
Sir Ernest Cassel is expected to arrive in Cairo almost immediately. The distinguished financier will stay for three weeks in Egypt
The clerk of the Central Criminal Coart,' Mr. H.K. Avory, who has been ia indifferent health for some time, hts left London for Bgypt on leave of absence.

Mrs. Donegan, wife tf Lieot.-Colonel Donegan, commanding 83rd Company Riyal Army Medioil Corps, Military Hospital, Citadel, has returned to Cairo from Aa*03aa, quite recovered from bar late indisposition.
Amongst the viritors we notice that Mrs. Twomey has also retnrned Trom Assouan and has taken up her reeidence at Ghezireh Palaoe.

M. Camille Saint-Saëàs, the well known French composer, has arrived in France from New York. He expressed great 8ati*rastion at the reception accorded in America to hi* works, whioh he condooted in different oities.

Sir Charles Wyndbam will spend the remainder of the winter in Egypt, in aooordanoa with his dootor'j advice. It is probable, however, that he will appear with Miss Mary Moore in a new play at the Criterion Theatre just after Easter.
Capt. E W. Macdonald, King's Own Scottish Borderers, has, on promotion, been appointed to the 1st Battalion, in Egypt.
Capt, R. G. Shuter, Manchester Regt., and ' Lient R. Micklem. R.E, have been appointed 2 muw ever 8 ; dQty ^ tfae EgyptiaQ Army.
Lient. H. W. Hadow, 1st Batt Blade Watch, has been seleoted 1er service with the Egyptian Army.

Among the latest arrivals at the Hotel d'Argleterre. Cairo, are Sir Robert Dash wood, Bart, and Dr. Northoote, Westleyoombe Park, Books ; Mr. and Mrs. Henry Close and Master Close, Ireland ; Lewa Ge igd Pasha, Alexandria ; Mr. and Mrs. R. Talbot Kelly and family, London ; Miss Browoly, Mrs. E. A. Merchant, Miss G. M. Wbincey, Miss E. A. White, England ; Capt and Mrs. B. Majendie, Miss E. Davidson, England ; Mro. A. P. Moor, Miss Moor, Troro ; Mr. J. F. Hopkins, Minieh ; Mr?. Ernest Hague. Misses Hague, Master C. N. Hague, Castle Dyke, Sheffield ; Mr. and Mrs. Wm. R. M. WiUie, New York ; Mr. F. B. Tarbell, Chicago -, Mrs. Wm. W. G. Steel, Miss Steel, Philadelphia ; Mro. H. C. Corson, Miss G. P. Wilson, Ohio ; Mr. and Mrs. A. Pownall, England ; Mr. J. N. Rennie, Green wioh; Mr. and Mrs. E. Skibbeck, England.

div.head:
THE LIVER AND STQMACH-
FACTS YOU OUGHT TO KNOW.
div.p: The liver and stomach, work harmoniously together, to chauge the food we eat into blood, bone, and tisane. The stomach sup plies the gastri j iice which digests the albuminous part of our food, and the bile from the liver completes the process of digestion by aoting on the oils and fats. The digested food is theD ready for conversion into pore, rich blood. Wheo,however,the stomaoh and liver are oat of ordsr, there is not enough gastric juice and bile formed to completely digest the food and form new blood, and the undigested food wearies aod irritates tbadelioate mechanism, and dogs the bowels. Doan's Dinner Pills stimulate the flow of gastrio juice and bile, thas directly aiding digestion and helping in the making of new, life-giving blood. This medicine should be used by all who have such symptoms of liver and stomach complaints as these*:—

Feeling of fulness, drowsiness and heaviness after meals ; stomach pains ; yellowness of the whites of the eyes ; heartburn ; indigestion ; spots before the eyes ; constipation ; vomiting; changeable appetite ; melaooholy feeling ; diffi- onlty in breathing ; tight feeling aoross the chest ; headache ; bad taste in the month. Doan's Dinner Pills are reliable, and they will core all stomaoh,liver and bowel troubles. This medioine may be bad of all ohemists and druggists, at 6 P.T. per box.

Ringworm, Eczema, Piles, and other Itohing Skin Dieeares are permanently oared by Doan's Ointment. This Ointment Is pare and olean, it does not irritate the »kin,or dry up too quickly. To be had of all ohemists and medicine- dealers ; 1 pot for 13 P.T.

div.head: PROSPECTUS.
div.p: THE COMPANY has been formed for the pnrpoaes stated in the Memorandum of Association, and more particularly to establish a line of British steamships to supply the demand made by the increasing passenger traffi 3 tor a first class and rapid eervica between Enrope and Egypt.

The Fairfield Shipbuilding and Engineering Company, Limited, of Glasgow, has contracted with the Company for the construction of two turbine steamers of aboot 18,000 tons gros» register, the length of the vessols to be 550 feet and breadth 60 feet. The steamers will each'have five turbines, viz:—three turbines for going ahead and two for going astern. They will each have three propellers and («wording to specifiation) are to steam not less than 20 A knots an hoar, at which speed the passage between Marseilles and Alexandria should be accomplished in 70 b >ars. Accommodation will be provided for 500 first class and 280 second class passengers.

In preparing the specific ition for thêta steamers, the Directors have had in view the recent great ad vaines that bava been myie in tb§ fitting of steameTa with the object of increasing the comfort of pMsengers. Besides state-room aroômmodation 'of the most up to- date character, a number of "cabinets de luxe," each with private bath room, etc., adj lining, will be provided, and in addition to the nsaal pnblio rooms there will be on the upper deck a restaurant (having separate kitch ins and service) in which meals will.be served at all b >ors à la carte.

In view of the ports, Marseilles and Alex andria, at which the steamers wi 1 call, special attention has been paid to ventilatiQp ; this will be effected by the tbermotank system by which the air in every part of the ships will be febaoged six time* an boar.
Other features will be as children's sa'o n and passenger hit comm-inicatlng with the varioos passenger deck».
I, will be seen that the Company's steam rs frill reproduce all the mos t Rtnkiof features
? the newest Atlantic lioera and as regarda comfort and apeed, will surpass anything hitherto attempted by any lines running be- •tween Earops and Egypt.

Lord Cromer'« R'port of the 8th March, 1906, containa the following reference with regard to the passenger traffi j with Earope;— " 1 have allnded in my resent Annual " Reports to the enormous increase which " has taken place during the last few years "in the passenger traffi> between Egypt " add Europe. In 1902, 60.000, and in 1903, " 74,000 passengers disembarked at Port "Said and Alexandria. Ii 1904 the total " number was 90,400. In 1905 it rose to " 99,922. These figures are exclusive of " troops, bo t include all cia «es of pa «sen- " gers."
The Directors believe that the special facilities which the Company's service will provide will appeal to the largely inoreaaiDg travelling ptfblio and will also prove highly remunerative.

The contraot price for the above-mentioned steamers is £6 6,000 payable in the nsoal red Shares. 26,640 Ordinary Shares and the ! mathod by instalments, whereof £406,000 is whole of (he 40,000 Deferred Shares have .payable doring construction, leaving £200,000 been allotted to thenvor their nominees at. par. payable On delivery of the steamers or at the The balaime, viz, 13 360 Ordinary Shares J Opti0Q 0f the Company by instalments extend- together wnh a further amount of 6,640 jDg 0ver two year».
Ordinary Shares, making in all. The Directors will in any event go to allot-
20,000 Ordinary Shares are now offered ment, having regard to the feet that the follow
